FacilityName: BEI Hawaii -  Barbers Point Facility, Oahu

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Emergency Response kit A&B; Recovery vessel (coffin) for 150 and 50 lbs cylinder; Fusible metal plug on the cylinder will melt while hot, thereby releasing gas/liquid without explosion.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Chlorine gas detector in the facility (test and inspect per bleach plant service schedule)
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Product manufacturer performs maintenance & inspection per DOT requirement
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Chlorine - Distribution       



BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility stores and distributes chlorine to the end users on the Oahu Island.  Because this product subject to OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program, it is subject to prevention program level 3.



BEI Hawaii has an OSHA PSM plan in place covering its operation.  This PSM program meets the requirements of the RMP prevention program and is thus utilized as the prevention program section of BEI Hawaii ? Barbers Point facility?s RMP.  All sections of the RMP prevention program are covered in the OSHA PSM program.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Fusible metal plug on the cylinder will melt while hot, thereby releasing gas/liquid without explosion.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Portable Drager CMS analyzer to detect a leak
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Product manufacturer performs maintenance & inspection per DOT requirement
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Sulfur Dioxide ? Distribution



BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility stores and distributes sulfur dioxide to an end user on the Island of Oahu.  This chemical is not regulated by the OSHA PSM program regulation and the NAICS code is not listed under the RMP program 3 (?68.19(d)).  Therefore, while we manage the process under program 3, this process is eligible for RMP program 2.



BEI Hawaii has a PSM plan in place covering this operation even through it is not required by OSHA PSM regulations.  The PSM program meets the requirements of the RMP prevention program and is thus utilized as the prevention program section of BEI Hawaii ? Barbers Point facility?s RMP.  All sections of the RMP prevention program are covered in the OSHA PSM program.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: High flow prevention valves shut off the operation if the flow is too rapid.   Internal and external pressure relief valves relieve pressure if pressure is higher than 265psi.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Portable Drager CMS analyzer to detect a leak
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Tanker maintenance and inspection are scheduled per DOT requirement
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Ammonia - Distribution



BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility distributes ammonia to the end user on the island of Oahu.  Because this product is subject to OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program , it is subject to prevention program level 3.  



BEI Hawaii has an OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program in place covering its operations. This PSM program meets the requirements of the RMP prevention program and is thus utilized as the prevention section of the BEI Hawaii-Barbers Point facility's RMP.  All sections of the RMP prevention program are covered in the OSHA PSM program.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Chlorine gas detector; Emergency Response Kit B; Fusible metal plug on the cylinder will melt while hot, thereby releasing gas/liquid without explosion.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Employees are extremely cautious when driving the forklift in the bleach plant
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Process pumps, transfer piping, monitor/sensors, etc.  Chlorine cylinders inspected by product manufacturer.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Chlorine - Bleach Manufacturer 



BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility produces liquid bleach. In the process of bleach production, chlorine is utilized.



One-ton chlorine containers (cylinders) are purchased from a West Coast supplier and shipped in 20? enclosed containers to Honolulu dock.  BEI Hawaii's CDL drivers pick up these containers and haul them to our Barbers Point facility at Campbell Industrial Park.  The containers remain on chassis within our secured facility until they are to be used in the production of sodium hypochlorite solution.  



When ready to be used, the cylinders are removed from the container via forklift and placed in sequence on a channel guideway.  This guideway enables the cylinders to slowly roll to the site where they are to be discharged into production.  Once at that site, two cylinders are positioned, via use of an overhead crane, so that their valves are properly aligned for connection to our discharge lines.  The cylinders are then connected by our trained operator to approved hoses which feed into our liquid chlorine lines.  Those lines pass through several valves and shutoffs into spargers which allow the chlorine to enter our reactor tanks via multiple tube openings just above the bottom of the tanks.  The presence of our process operator, along with various shutoffs and automated controllers, facilitate safe passage and discharge of the chlorine into the caustic soda/water mix within the reactors.



When the pressure of chlorine exiting the cylinders drops to approximately 25 psi, signaling that the cylinder is near empty, the system shuts down and the operator must manually feed the chlorine through the line valves until the cylinders reach near-atmospheric pressure.  The cylinder/hose connections are then closed, cylinder valves are shut, the lines purged with nitrogen, and disengaged from the cylinders.



At this point, the cylinders that are now emptied, are lifted by overhead crane from their feed position and placed on a roller conveyor.  They are then rolled the length of a cylinder to an area where they can be picked up via forklift and transported to a holding rack.  When sufficient empties are collected, they are loaded into a shipping container for booking and returned back to the West Coast supplier.

_accidents.CF_Other: There was a precautionary evacuation in the Campbell Industrial Park due to the wind direction.
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Requested the manufacturer to investigate what caused the cylinder bulge and the small leak from fusible plugs

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is prepared for the BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility.  BEI Hawaii developed the site specific Risk Management Plans for its facilities that are regulated under the risk management program to comply with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention requirements: Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) and to protect public safety and the environment.  The goal of our risk management program is to prevent serious chemical accidents that could cause harm to our employees, the general public, and the environment, and to reduce the potential impact of an accidental release.      



This RMP consists of five chapters.  Chapter 1, Introduction and Management System, introduces the plans and describes the facility operations, management and responsibilities.  Chapter 2, Hazardous Assessment, provides an overview of the chemicals stored in our Barbers Point facility, their hazard release consequences and impact in worst case and alternative scenarios.  Chapter 3, Five-Year Accident History, provides the guideline for accident release investigation.  Chapter 4, Prevention Program, explains that BEI Hawaii uses its Process Safety Management (PSM) plans to provide process safety information, hazard analysis, operation procedures, and prevention procedures.  PSM is specific to each chemical and process.  Chapter 5, Summary of Emergency Response program, provides the guideline for what to do in case of an emergency. 



Following briefly describes our facility's risk management program:



1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



BEI Hawaii believes in a clean and safe environment and is dedicated to meeting all applicable environmental standards in the operation of its businesses and services.  BEI Hawaii has established comprehensive policies and procedures for the operations of its facilities.  The policy is a commitment to environmental compliance th

at assigns the responsibility of implementing the policy to Chief Executive Officer of the company, or designated individual or individuals to ensure compliance.  The purpose of the policy is to provide employees with a safe and healthy working environment, and to protect the environment from pollution.



Preservation of the environment is a commitment that must be shared by all employees.  Employees shall promptly report suspected violations of environmental laws, regulations or permits to their supervisor who shall take immediate action to verify the report and, if confirmed, stop the violation and take remedial or other appropriate action.  The incident shall be promptly reported to BEI Hawaii - Regulatory Compliance Officer, who will assist in making any necessary reports to regulatory agencies.



The overall approach to chemical safety begins with the premise that safety is everyone's responsibility and working safely is a condition of employment.  Workplace hazards are minimized through preventive measures such as facility and equipment design, purchase of less hazardous products and development of standard operating procedures.  Control measures include facility inspections to discover potential problems, employee reports of hazardous conditions, and training  programs.   



2.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 



Our BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility is located at 91-150 Kaomi Loop, Kapolei, on the island of Oahu.  The site is leasehold with Hawaii Phoenix Properties LLC being the ground lessor and consists of approximately 5.7 acres.  The site is bounded on the north by Chevron Hawaii Refinery, south and east by undeveloped parcels, and the Pacific Ocean and shoreline to the west.  The facility stores mostly bulk industrial chemicals.  The products are mainly warehoused at the facility and distributed to various locations throughout Oahu as well as throughout the State of Hawaii.  This facility also manufactures bleach, the main ingredients o

f which are chlorine and liquid caustic.  The regulated substances handled at this facility are chlorine, sulfur dioxide (anhydrous), and anhydrous ammonia.  All the materials are prepackaged by manufacturers in Department of Transportation (DOT) approved cylinders or tankers.  BEI Hawaii receives them from chemical suppliers and distributors located on the west coast.  The suppliers are responsible for container inspection and maintenance.  Because bulk sales are made directly to customers, access to the facility is not restricted.



3.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Steps



BEI Hawaii has an OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program in place covering its operations.  This PSM program meets the requirements of the RMP and is thus utilized as the prevention section of the BEI Hawaii-Barbers Point facility's RMP.  All sections of the RMP prevention program are covered in the OSHA PSM program.   The OSHA PSM plan and documentation are maintained in the Regulatory Compliance Officer's office and at the facility.  



Four PSM plans have been developed for this facility which include storage of chlorine, sulfur dioxide (anhydrous), anhydrous ammonia, and the bleach manufacturing (sodium hypochlorite) plant.  For the storage of chlorine and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous), the important practices to the prevention program are proper storage and handling of the cylinders.  Proper loading and unloading of cylinders from trucks are very important to prevent cylinders from falling and causing possible damage to the valve area.  For the storage of anhydrous ammonia, the important practices to the prevention program are proper handling of the transport tank.  Training and careful work practices are the key to preventing accidental damage to the cylinders.  For the bleach manufacturing plant, the important practices to the prevention program are having a careful and cautious operator, proper operation of the equipment following the standard operati

on procedures, inspecting and testing the equipment following the good engineering practices or manufacturer recommendations, and conducting regular maintenance.  Further details of each element of each process are described in Barbers Point facility's four PSM plans.  



4.  Five-Year Accident History



The facility has had no accidents and no release that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage from sulfur dioxide and ammonia during the last five years.  



The facility had very small emissions of chlorine gas from two fusible plugs of a one-ton cylinder on May 22, 2009.  The release was estimated less than 3 lbs and it was sealed within approximately 15 minutes.  A bulge was noticed on the bulkhead of the cylinder which resulted in a precautionary evacuation in the Campbell Industrial Park to ensure the safety of the general public.  There were no deaths, injuries, significant property damage, or environmental damage on site and off site.  



5.  Emergency Response Program



The BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility is classified as a non-responding facility.  As such, BEI Hawaii has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employee/community safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response with an in-house response team.  The BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point Facility has developed its own procedures as outlined in the BEI Hawaii Safety and Health Program incorporating information from Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 64, Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities and others.  BEI Hawaii has coordinated response to incidents with the Honolulu Fire Department Hazmat Team located on Oahu.  Operators are capable, however, of responding to incidental releases such as routine tightening of a valve, for example. 



BEI Hawaii - Barbers Point facility personnel will only perform defensive mitigation measures (i.e., secure areas, initiate water spray, etc.) to limit the release until a response team arrives to establish the incident command.

We have discussed this program with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Honolulu Fire Department.  In addition, BEI Hawaii has arranged with local response contractors to deal with potential releases at the facility.  



6.  Planned change to improve safety



There is no plan to change the present operation for chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and anhydrous ammonia primarily because the process is storage.  Over the years BEI Hawaii has eliminated several other chemicals and reduced the chemical inventory amount.  Chlorine use, especially by swimming pools and sewage treatment plants, is being eliminated and substituted with bleach or hypochlorite in powdered or tablet form depending on the facility.  This will enable BEI Hawaii to further reduce the facility's chlorine inventory.
